Information can be passed into functions as arguments. Arguments are specified after the function name inside the parentheses. You can add as many arguments as you want and separate them with a comma.
The following example has a function with one argument (fname). When the function is called, we pass along a first name, which is used inside the function to print the full name:
functions-args_key11: Here we give numbers_list to the max function and it gives us the largest value out of it.
functions-args_key12: max function, is one of the pre-define function, where no need to defined the def max() to write the code of block because the creator of Python has already done this work for us.
functions-args_key13: Similarly, the len function also takes a list and gives us the count of items in the list.
functions-args_key14: We use the len( ) function to find the length of an array or sequence. It is also the python pre-define function.
functions-args_key21: Here we have defined the function in the same way as in the previous example. Notice that the after def say_hello in the function brackets we write name and the below of that we write the name variable with the print command. Here the name is called * parameter * whose value we can give at the time of calling the function.While calling the function in the last line, we have written "Atif" inside the brackets. The parameters we assign values ​​while calling a function are called arguments.
